docs.lead_paragraph: THE potential dangers from naturally occurring radon, a gas that has been found trapped in many homes in northern New Jersey, have stirred as much public concern as, if not more than, that surrounding the worst chemical waste dumps in the state. A measure that would address the problem and provide $3.2 million for a comprehensive evaluation of the dangers has been under review by the State Senate for six weeks. Meanwhile, state environmental officials and others familiar with radon say that exposure to it may be developing into the No. 1 environmental problem of the decade. This is so, they say, if only because of the numbers of people theatened: tens of thousands in parts of Morris, Hunterdon, Warren, Sussex, Somerset, Bergen and Monmouth Counties.
